title: Strategy needs to constantly evolve.
text:
Ask yourself "Why are you doing this?"
Note your primary responses.
Reflect on the observations.

title:
Strategy is all about
the big-picture choices.
text:
Be clear about what you are going to (not) do.
Define concrete activities to fulfill your goals.
Craft and adhere to schedule.

title:
How to build time
for strategic thinking?
text:
Turn down the noise (e.g. music or TV).
Sit with your thoughts.
Ask the big questions.
Schedule for an hour a week.

title: Gain diverse inspiration.
text:
Consider all the present the future and the past.
Identify industry leaders and follow their content.
Monitor trends - Read widely and often.

title: How to create an informed strategy?
text:
Good strategy doesn't have to be innovative.
Look at the past successes (including competition).
Consider upcoming trends in the industry.
Solicit input from diverse sources.

title: How to turn strategy into reality?
text:
Map all available assets and allies.
Make use of key relationships.
Identify main constraints and obstacles.
Create specific goals and related steps.

title: Roll out your strategy continually.
text:
Don't reveal it all at a single meeting.
Have premeetings with key people.
Identify objections and prepare arguments.
Create key action points.

title: Measure your success.
text:
Clarify major goals and metrics.
Evaluate the progress on a regular basis.
Identify tracking methods in advance.
Document the process and study mistakes.

title:
Executing strategy is
an ongoing process.
text:
Follow the strategy unless it has critical flaws.
Is there a major change in circumstances?
Is there a more promising alternative?
Are the expectations failing?

title: Put your team first and build trust.
text:
Prioritise team goals over your own.
Reveal any personal gains from the shared effort.
Express appreciation of others' work.

title: Underpromise and overdeliver.
text:
Acknowledge existing constraints.
Keep your commitments.
Deliver valuable results.
Communicate updates regularly.

title:
Demonstrate positivity
in any situation.
text:
Highlight teammates' strengths.
Refrain from gossiping.
Avoid complaining.

title: Be respectful to your colleagues.
text:
People remember how you make them feel.
Avoid making things personal.
Respect set boundaries.
Don't waste their time.

title: Ideal teammate is adequately proactive.
text:
Plan ahead and anticipate the roadblocks.
Think in a context of the whole organisation.
Help to get back on track if you are losing direction.
Avoid being too intrusive.

title:
Stay collaborative regardless
of your opinion.
text:
Encourage the participation of others.
Support team-based decisions.
Share your ideas and concerns.

title: Build your professional reputation.
text:
Continuously develop your skills.
Fulfill deadlines and maintain high quality.
Speak and dress to represent the team positively.

title: Be an awesome team player.
text:
Balance work and building relationships.
Value the people more than the outcomes.
Encourage learning from mistakes.
Be flexible.

title:
Avoid judgement based
on minimal information.
text:
Use data to analyse critical situations.
Consider various perspectives and motivations.
Embrace your instincts and feelings.
Integrate all the above.

title:
Data + Information + Analysis
= Best judgement
text:
Find confirming and disconfirming data.
Look at the forest and also at a single tree.
What may be the best and worst possible outcome?

title: Judge trustworthiness not likeability.
text:
Does the person meet the expectations?
Does the person fulfill their commitments?
Has the person ever cheated or lied?

title: Good judgement requires clean head.
text:
Smile to reduce body stress response.
Write notes by hand and review them.
Let others know if you need to slow down.

title:
Judge your own arguments
using the right questions.
text:
Did I highlight a common ground?
Did I make my main claim clear?
Did I provide sufficient evidence?
Did I omit personal attacks?

title: How to judge the future?
text:
Avoid saying "I knew it all along".
Pick three industry leaders.
Create a question wishlist.
Ask the leaders the questions.
Integrate various sources and formats.

title: Become more self-aware.
text:
What type of people do I prefer to work with?
What makes me stop listening to people?
What type of people prefer to work with me?
What makes people stop listening me?

title: Avoid jumping to conclusions.
text:
Balance negative thoughts with gratitude.
Secret does not automatically mean important.
Confident does not mean competent.

title:
Donâ€™t rush to solve a problem.
Stop and think first.
Dig down to avoid solving symptoms.
Find and address the root cause.

Think twice about your
recommended solutions.
text:
What problems might they cause?
Will it actually help the situation?
Review your approach with others.

title:
Break big problems
into smaller ones.
text:
Then break those into smaller as well.
Continue until the solutions become obvious.
Anticipate unintended consequences.

title: Define the problem statement.
text:
Outline essential goals and main metrics.
Identify key stakeholders and define success.
Map boundaries and constraints.
Articulate assumptions and create a timeline.

title:
Seek to understand
why a solution is needed.
text:
What is really driving the request?
Why do people care about it?
Is it really a serious problem?

title:
Examine the past attempts
to solve the problem.
text:
Who and how tried to solve it?
What were the limitations?
What is different now?

title: Use the â€œ80/20â€ rule.
text:
20% of input leads to 80% of the results.
Analyse and prioritise opportunities.
What are the major impact drivers?

title: Ask yourself â€œSo what?â€ 5+ times.
text:
Ask about the action consequences.
Spot any new opportunities or threats.
Avoid causing unexpected problems.

title: Ask yourself â€œwhyâ€ 5+ times.
text:
The root cause is usually masked by other issues.
Ask why something happens to think about the reasons.
Ask again and again until you get to the core.

title:
How to do successful analysis?
Ask yourself questions.
text:
What am I proving or disproving?
Will it be beneficial?
Will it have enough impact?
Do the answers support my solutions?

title: Apply critical thinking every day.
text:
Avoid following "That's the way it's always doneâ€.
Identify a problem and break it down.
Focus on the meaningful.
Look for new solutions.

title:
Reduce common risks
related to public releases.
text:
Itâ€™s all about understanding customers.
Make sure the product is a good fit.
Do your research.

title: Demonstrate empathy with users.
text:
Describe their feelings towards a product.
Observe words used to describe it.
Compare your product with competition.
Understand what customers need.

title: Frame the problem.
text:
Explain and describe the context.
Focus on customer understanding.
Depict â€œwhoâ€ â€œwhyâ€ â€œwhatâ€ and â€œwhereâ€.

title: Ideate and innovate.
text:
Challenge common assumptions.
Pursue innovative solutions.
Understand specific needs.
Develop adequate solutions.

title: Provoke feedback by a prototype.
text:
Use anything that makes users reveal information.
Observe what they do and feel.
Define the type of feedback you look for.

title: Test your solutions and iterate.
text:
Start with something simple.
Gather valuable feedback as early as possible.
Resolve the most severe issues and repeat.

title: Observe customerâ€™s own solutions.
text:
Understand what is their main goal.
Note their actions and tools.
Utilise these in your proposal.

title: Feedback is a tool for improvement.
text:
Avoid speaking in general "You always..."
Focus on specific actions and feelings.
Avoid personal attacks.

title: Reveal your blind spots.
text:
Recognize the difference among
intention and perception.
Ask for other's opinions.

title: Accept the possibility of making mistakes.
text:
Your thoughts and feelings create your story.
Practice by accepting feedback.
Focus on the positives.
Learn from any mistakes.

title: Take control over receiving feedback.
text:
Don't react right away.
Take your time to process it.
Separate opinions and facts.
Create a forward focus.

title: How to ask for feedback?
text:
Ask about a specific area.
Get opinions of multiple people.
Be grateful for others' responses.
Look out for any non-verbal clues.

title: Give feedback effectively.
text:
Prepare the main message in advance.
Balance positive and negative feedback.
Focus on using a supportive tone.

title: Explore the facts and concrete examples.
text:
Gather multiple examples rather than only one.
Distinguish between opinions and facts.
Ask for alternative point of view.

title: Focus on listening carefully.
text:
The others may have opposite opinion.
Try to understand their point of view.
Demonstrate empathy.

title: Create a forward focus.
text:
Frame the feedback constructively.
Focus on the upcoming opportunities.
Explore space for any improvements.

title: Get credibility and self-awareness.
text:
Understand and communicate your motivations.
Stop your internal narrative and urge to defend.
Notice your stress triggers and needs.
Let go of the illusion of perfection.

title: Transparency starts with valuable facts.
text:
Observe and understand different perspectives.
Ask key stakeholders direct questions.
Sit back and go through all information.
Research to fill any gaps.

title: Build respect and trust.
text:
Help others understand your actions.
Reveal your personal motivations.
Keep your promises.

title: Avoid radical transparency.
text:
Do not blindly share any information.
Adjust your tone to the audience.
Include the context and suggest solutions.

title: Develop and express authenticity.
text:
Don't fear what others might think.
Start conversations with a known truth.
Highlight the key points.
Be emotionally neutral.

title: Be empathetic and understand others.
text:
What would you want to know?
How would it make you feel?
Could there be any long lasting impacts?

title: Keep up transparency integrity.
text:
Don't ever lie or hide facts.
Avoid taking reactions personally.
Respect the feelings of others.

title: Learn to accept criticism.
text:
You won't be always popular.
Sometimes the truth hurts.
Give others space to express themselves.
Avoid being defined by circumstances.

title: How do good decisions look like?
text:
They achieve the desired outcome.
They fit the culture and context.
Team can commit to them.

title: When to decide independently?
text:
The outcome is likely to be supported.
All key information is available.
The problem is not shared by others.
It is an urgent matter.

title: When to decide collaboratively?
text:
The problem is shared by others.
Additional information is required.
Time frame is reasonable.

title: How to get critical information?
text:
Has something similar been done before?
Seek insight from the previously involved.
Who can bring a different perspective?

title: How to decide collaboratively?
text:
Don't ask if you are already decided.
Give people enough time to respond.
Keep an open mind and don't judge.
Give everyone a chance to express.

title: Avoid waiting too long.
text:
Remember the main purpose and impact.
Is it desirable to decide ASAP?
Is the decision reversible? Go on.

title:
Take a last good look
before making a decision.
text:
Will the desired goal criteria be met?
Is there enough commitment from the others.
Do you have a reasonable plan?

title: Communicate the decisions right.
text:
Tailor the format to the audience.
Share the problem and main motivation.
Present specific next steps.
Support starting a dialogue.

title:
Prepare meeting agenda
and desired outcomes.
text:
Do your research in advance.
Share the agenda early.
Identify any blind spots.
Meeting = 3+ people

title: How to craft a perfect agenda?
text:
Outline topics and desired outcomes.
Include a rough timeline.
Share it early in the invitation.
Recap it at the start of the meeting.

title:
Stay focused and prepare
for effectiveness.
text:
Pre-read the upcoming agenda.
Look for related information.
Prepare your thoughts.
Remove distractions (set phone to DND).

title: Facilitate better virtual meetings.
text:
Wait for an input and give more time.
Ensure everyone understands.
Call on people individually.
Ask specific questions.

title:
Hybrid meeting with people
both online & on-site
text:
Pretest the technology with both parties.
Speak loud and slow enough.
Engage on-call people first.
...or make it virtual for everyone.

title: Improve online meetings.
text:
Ask others to use the webcams.
Look at the others instead of yourself.
Use the raise a hand function or chat.
Ask about the surroundings to start lightly.

title: Collect ideas effectively.
text:
Encourage others to express their thoughts.
Have a "parking lot" for unrelated topics.
Return to them if there's a time left.

title: Produce clear action points.
text:
Focus on key tasks and their owners.
Write meeting notes as you go.
Summarize the outcomes before ending the meeting.
Report progress regularly.

title: Networking 101
text:
Avoid basic questions like "What do you do?".
Instead prepare talking points in advance.
Demonstrate authentic interest.
Allow yourself to have a time alone.

title: Understand the difference.
text:
Compliance vs Commitment
Forced Approach vs Choice
Passive vs Active Participation
Paycheck vs Purpose Motivation

title: How to get a commitment of the others?
text:
Accept more ambiguity of execution.
Give others enough responsibility.
Be committed yourself.
Demonstrate dedication.

title: Your role as a team member
text:
Encourage and support others.
Always participate actively.
Ask good questions.
Help the group decide.

title:
Communicate effectively
with your team.
text:
Message has to be received and understood.
Fully focus on your audience.
Ask more and assert less.
Give others space to talk.

title: How to drive team performance?
text:
Believe that the team can succeed.
Set clear expectations.
Show the impact of the work.
Provide ongoing feedback.
Be a role model for the behaviour.

title: Help others set goals.
text:
Explain why goals are necessary for growth.
Outline the purpose for the organisation.
Provide a smooth setup process.
Encourage and give enough space for completion.

title: How to avoid micromanagement?
text:
Be flexible and understand others' needs.
Focus on the "what" more than on "how".
Set expectations and check-in plan.
Resist the need for power.

title: Delegate tasks effectively.
text:
Understand that delegation is an investment.
Continuously build trust with others.
Be available and provide a safety net.

title: Delegate tasks successfully.
text:
Ask "why" and "what" are you delegating.
Are you willing to let this go?
Who is the best person to do it?
Provide essential support.
Check in regularly.

title: How to delegate tasks?
text:
Set an objective and provide context + timeline.
Provide expectations and describe the success.
Adjust the priorities relative to existing tasks.
Cooperate on building a specific plan.

title:
Organise successful meetings.
State "why" are you meeting.
Provide the expected outcomes.
Focus on reaching decisions.
Talk less and ask more.

Build strong relationship
with your team.
text:
Get to know their interests and passions.
Search for a common ground.
Follow up on discussed topics.
Smile!

title: Manage your time wisely.
text:
Work on a single task at a time.
Keep the big objectives in focus.
Schedule the most important work.
Respond to e-mails in batches.

title: Manage up successfully.
text:
Understand your supervisor's goals.
Connect your requests to their goals.
Create conversations by asking questions.
Focus on the common ground more than on yourself.

title: Have a learning mindset.
text:
Ask follow up questions.
Reflect on your learnings.
Ask for and be open to feedback.
Don't agonize your mistakes.

title: Put all unexpected changes in context.
text:
Many things change every day.
Change is an essential part of life.
You don't have to face it alone.

title: Embracing changes takes skill.
text:
Let the emotions settle a bit in the first place.
Remember that you are in charge of your life.
Turn changes into opportunities for growth.
Always consider the broader context.

title: Seek an objective perspective.
text:
Step back and avoid any immediate reaction.
Discuss different views with your close ones.
Consider previous experiences of you and others.

title: Build personal resilience.
text:
Identify your parts unthreatened by the change.
Be grateful for what you have and you'll keep.
Invest in your mental and physical health.
Choose to view things positively.

title: What's positivity and why is it important?
text:
It does not mean ignoring problems.
It means being in "solution first" mode.
Engage in being positive and impress others.
Encourage such behaviour among your team.

title: Minimise negative thoughts.
text:
Try imaging the worst/best and most likely cases.
Counter negative thoughts with facts.
Assume the best of others' intentions.
Change the story in your head.

title: Embrace positive thinking.
text:
Be grateful for common but essential things.
Do frequent adjustments to your living space.
Find the positive triggers in your environment.
Put together a positivity portfolio.

title: Develop positive relationships.
text:
Strive for celebrating others' good news.
Make far more positive than negative comments.
Consider doing random acts of kindness.

title: Foster positive habits.
text:
Balance work and play well enough.
Set an end-time for working hours.
Frequently leverage your strengths.
Find some joy in your work.

title: Respond adequately to negativity.
text:
Practice empathy and acknowledge the feelings.
Redirect your focus on possible improvements.
Protect your positive zone by distancing.

title: How to respond to failure or loss?
text:
Avoid extreme words such as always/worst/never...
Create some space for all stages of grief.
Focus on reengagement and success.

title: Identify your stress triggers.
text:
What elevates your stress level?
Where does it come from?
When it usually happens?
Name specific activities and places.

title: Take control over your availability.
text:
You are not required to be reachable non-stop.
Selectively disconnect for a preset time.
Try working in a different environment.
Use the "Do not disturb" mode.
Work off-site once in a while.

title: Manage your interactions.
text:
Not all meetings are mandatory by default.
Minimise interactions with your stress triggers.
Proactively seek positively influential opportunities.

title: Take control over your schedule.
text:
Try to begin your day at work early.
Start with the most challenging tasks.
Consciously take 5 min breaks 2+ times a day.
Learn how to say "No" when necessary.

title: Make positive personal choices.
text:
Imagine yourself actually working on your desires.
Engage in fun and socially stimulating activities.
Focus on the good things and be grateful.
Refine your diet and workout plan.

title: What is personal resilience?
text:
It's the ability to not break down under pressure.
Employ empathy and regulate emotional responses.
Stay cool even when being disturbed.

title: Practice response to rejection.
text:
Get accustomed to hearing "No".
Try asking for things you might not receive.
Keep your internal dialogue positive.
Avoid apologizing for every minor hiccup.

title: Willingly face uncomfortable situations.
text:
Get yourself an extra assignment.
Try exploring some new field.
Don't give up too early.
Learn from any failures.

title: Manage your energy efficiently.
text:
Schedule any challenges for your productive hours.
When are you the most productive?
Is it in the morning/afternoon/evening?
Maybe you need to warmup first?

title: Practice positive thinking.
text:
The words you imagine and say alter your mood.
Negative events are usually temporary.
Focus on things under your control.
Don't dwell on the little things.

title: Reflect on your previous reactions.
text:
What could you have done differently?
Did you handle the situation appropriately?
Did you focus on being positive?

title: Take a break and then come back.
text:
Take disciplined breaks to cool down regularly.
Go elsewhere and engage in a different activity.
Review and prioritise action points later.
Redirect your energy focus.

title: Become self-aware and utilize it.
text:
Repeatedly ask yourself "Who are you?"
Focus on your traits and not your actions.
Understand your needs and feelings.
See how your choices affect others.
Reflect on the observations.

title: Learn how to regulate your emotions.
text:
Observe your emotional triggers in real time.
Don't act out nor totally suppress emotions.
Avoid spending energy on negative self-talk.
Identify and learn from unpleasant events.

title: Nurture your relationships.
text:
Having a close friend at your workplace
rises chances for higher engagement.
Look for people with specific traits.
Seek loyalty and respect. Build trust.

title: Practice empathy at work.
text:
Avoid quick judgement and stereotyping.
Be patient and attentive listener.
Express genuine interest.
Ask follow-up questions.

title: Influence others without authority.
text:
Build strong credibility and trust.
Influence through real-life storytelling.
Mind your attitude and value relationships.
Ask others for their support.

title: Listen actively to truly understand.
text:
Don't plan your response in advance.
Always avoid interrupting others.
Notice gestures and visual cues.
Acknowledge and recap learnings.

title: Tailor your communication approach.
text:
Get to know the audience traits and desires.
Imagine yourself being in their shoes.
Be clear on what you need to share.
Think how you want them to feel.

title: Overcome the fear of public speaking.
text:
Focus on the message and not on yourself.
Prepare essential talking points ahead of time.
Form deep connections by expressing energy.
Employ storytelling to engage the audience.

title: Get good at small talk.
text:
Change your mindset - it's not a waste of time.
Initiate discussions about your favourite topics.
Ask open ended questions and let others speak.
Share something about yourself.

title: Embrace a new perspective on time.
text:
World is filled with distractions and opportunities.
Create proper filters for your interactions.
Aim focus on the most valuable inputs.
Make sure you choose your actions.

title: Value your time and attention.
text:
Ask yourself "Is this really a valuable activity?"
Imagine how much it could be worth per hour.
The higher the value the more freedom you create.
Rank available opportunities and choose wisely.

title: Eliminate low-value activities.
text:
Don't waste time with negative thoughts or self-talk.
Refrain from engaging in any internet arguments.
Rule out addictive and destructive behaviour.
Set filters for notifications and e-mail inbox.

title: Reschedule things you are not sure about.
text:
Gather promising ideas and review them later.
Some may turn out to be groundbreaking.
Schedule a recurring "Perhaps List Review".
Keep everything in written form.

title: Schedule for later if there's enough space.
text:
Actions with low or delayed value can be postponed.
Ask yourself "When is the latest time I need this?"
Set a reminder and get back to it later.

title: Automate any recurring high-value tasks.
text:
A small investment can save a lot over a long time.
Almost anything can be at least partially automated.
Think about both proper and "hacky" solutions.
Focus on progress and not on perfection.
Start with the most trivial parts.

title: Delegate if someone is better suited.
text:
Consider if there's more value in doing it yourself.
Delegation = Provide instructions and expectations.
Abdication = Make a request and await success.
Practice passing on tasks of high value.

title: Focus on the tasks you perform the best.
text:
Switch from being busy to being highly valuable.
Does it take just about 5 minutes? Then do it now!
Set up a reminder for anything longer than that.
The higher the value the sooner you should do it.

title: Embrace a collaborative mindset.
text:
Identify your unique strengths and start using them.
All skills can be improved but some come naturally.
Create a skill wishlist and practice these with others.
Discover what makes people shine and encourage it.

title: Practice proven habits of team-players.
text:
Always build good relationships with colleagues.
Reserve a high-focus time for your energy peaks.
Accept possible imperfections and differences.
Celebrate achievements and reflect on the journey.

title: Think big and think small.
text:
Thinking big = Imagine the desired work end results.
Thinking small = Identify the mission critical steps.
Combine both perspectives into a plan outline.
Set up tasks and expectations collaboratively.
